valid_articles.Title: Reddit's ad revenue to reach $1.1B+ in 2024

valid_articles.Title: Oh, and here's my case study about redirects to non-relevant urls, and Google seeing those as soft 404s. Again, 404s are totally fine, and can be good. Don't blind redirect urls to categories, your homepage, etc.
valid_articles.Description: Tweet from user @glenngabe sharing a case study about redirects to non-relevant URLs and how Google interprets them as soft 404 errors. The tweet emphasizes that using 404 errors is acceptable and often preferable to blindly redirecting URLs to irrelevant pages like category pages or the homepage.

valid_articles.Title: Having many noindexed pages is NOT a sign of low quality...
valid_articles.Description: Tweet thread from user @glenngabe discussing how having a large number of noindexed pages on a website does not necessarily indicate poor website quality. The thread challenges the misconception that a high volume of noindexed URLs equates to low-quality content and provides insights based on the user's experience working with clients.
